standard.description: These are standards to maintain Accessibility.

test.test_name: List templates should avoid inline CSS w blinking or animation
test.query_clob:
with aatl as ( select case
                      when (lower(trim(inline_css)) like '%blink%'
                            or lower(trim(inline_css)) like '%animation%') 
                      then 'N' 
                      else 'Y'
                      end pass_yn,
                      template_name, 
                      inline_css,
                      last_updated_by,
                      last_updated_on,
                      workspace,
                      list_template_id,
                      application_id
               from APEX_APPLICATION_TEMP_LIST
            )
select aatl.pass_yn,
       aatl.workspace,
       aatl.application_id, 
       null page_id,
       null created_by,
       null created_on,
       aatl.last_updated_by,
       aatl.last_updated_on,
       apex_string.format('List Template `%0` (app %1) has a CSS animation : `%2`', 
        p0 => aatl.template_name, 
        p1 => aatl.application_id,
        p2 => aatl.inline_css) validation_failure_message,
       apex_string.format('List Template `%0` (app %1) has a CSS animation', 
        p0 => aatl.template_name, 
        p1 => aatl.application_id) issue_title,
       aatl.list_template_id component_id,
       null parent_component_id,
       aatl.template_name,
       aatl.inline_css
from aatl
where aatl.workspace = svt_preferences.get_preference ('SVT_DEFAULT_WORKSPACE')
test.explanation:
This test is tied to the following WCAG Codes :

1.  2.2.2(A) : Pause, Stop, Hide:  
    For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true:
    
    Moving, blinking, scrolling  
    For any moving, blinking or scrolling information that (1) starts automatically, (2) lasts more than five seconds, and (3) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it unless the movement, blinking, or scrolling is part of an activity where it is essential; and
    
    Auto-updating  
    For any auto-updating information that (1) starts automatically and (2) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it or to control the frequency of the update unless the auto-updating is part of an activity where it is essential.
